fields: Infections of the brain substance (parenchyma) include {{c1::encephalitis}} and {{c1::intracranial abscess}}.
Intracranial abscesses can have the following locations - {{c1::epidural}}, subdural, {{c1::meningeal}} and {{c1::intra}}cerebral.
Etiology of intracranial abscesses can include a {{c1::metastatic}} infection (e.g. endocarditis), post-{{c1::meningitis}} (children <5 yrs) and other sources e.g. trauma, neurosurgery etc.
can spread from an adjacent focus: paranasal sinuses, middle ear/mastoid (mastoiditis)

Common organisms that can cause intracranial abscesses include {{c1::streptococci}} in the sinuses, {{c1::anaerobes}} in the middle ear, {{c1::S.aureus}}, Clostridium, GNB in trauma, {{c1::staphylococci}}, GNB in surgery, and haematogenous depends on the source (e.g. staph viridans strep if endocarditis).

Intracranial abscesses are influenced by the {{c1::size}} or location of the abscess, {{c1::virulence}} of pathogens, and underlying {{c1::disease}}. Clinical features can include {{c1::headaches}}, fever (<50%), raised {{c1::ICP}} (altered mental status, papilloedema, nausea etc.). Symptoms and signs in {{c1::immunocompromised}} individuals can be subtle.

Lumbar punctures have a risk of brain {{c1::herniation}} of the {{c1::parenchyma}}. Types include {{c1::Tentorial}}, {{c1::Subfalcine}}, {{c1::Tonsillar}} (cerebellum). Main diagnostic tests include {{c1::CT}} or {{c1::MRI}} which have ring-enhancing lesions with IV contrast.

{{c1::Encephalitis}} is inflammation (diffuse) of CNS parenchyma. It varies in degrees of severity. Clinical features can include {{c1::headaches}}, fever, and neck {{c1::stiffness}} if mild, {{c1::focal}} signs and {{c1::personality}} changes if moderate, and seizures, altered {{c1::mental}} status, raised {{c1::ICP}}, coma, etc. if severe.
The organism that causes the most concern in encephalitis is {{c1::Herpes Simplex Virus I}}.
Most commonly, HSV 1 causes cold sores around the mouth and lips and can cause genital herpes (but most are caused by Type 2).

{{c1::Arboviruses}} such as the West Nile, St.Louis, Eastern Equine, Japanese encephalitis virus, etc. are also an aetiological agent for Encephalitis. Additionally, {{c1::enteroviruses}} such as HIV/mumps/measles, {{c1::Non-viral}} diseases such as Listeria/Lyme disease/TB/Toxoplasma, etc. or post-{{c1::infection}} with mumps/measles/rubella.. can also cause encephalitis.

{{c1::Meningitis}} is a global problem. There are >1.2 million cases annually;>10% cases fatal. 10-15% of them have long term disabilities such as loss of {{c1::digit/limb}}, seizures, {{c1::hearing}} loss, {{c1::intellectual}} deficits, depression, and chronic {{c1::renal}} failure.

{{c1::Viral}} meningitis is a common cause of 'culture-negative' meningitis. Examples include {{c1::enteroviruses}} - seasonal variation (late summer/early autumn), {{c1::HSV}} 2, mumps, etc. Some degree of headaches and neck {{c1::stiffness}} can occur. {{c1::Lymphocytes}} can be found in the CSF (neutrophils at early stages). This is usually self-limiting.

General causes of bacterial meningitis involve {{c1::neisseria meningitidis}}, haemophilus influenza (rare), and {{c1:: streptococcus pneumoniae}} - very common in causes in {{c1::infants}}. Special groups could include {{c1::E.Coli}}, streptococcus agalactia (Group B strep), listeria monocytogenes, and {{c1::Mycobacterium Tuberculosis}}.

{{c1::Fungal}} meningitis is caused by cryptococcus neoformans. It occurs in {{c1::immunocompromised}} individuals (e.g. AIDS, steroid RX, organ transplantation, DM, malignancy, etc.) and can have a {{c1::subacute}} onset - headache, {{c1::lethargy}}, cranial nerve {{c1::palsies}}, hydrocephalus etc.

Neisseria Meningitidis is a gram {{c1::negative}} aerobic diplococci. It causes {{c1::meningitis}}, sepsis/septic shock. It can also cause {{c1::pneumonia}} (10%), septic arthritis, etc. The natural reservoir of this bacteria are {{c1::humans}} with 5-10% of adults being {{c1::asymptomatic}} carriers.
Peak carriage rates in 15-19 yrs age group (up to 25%).

{{c1::N.meningitidis}} is the commonest bacterial pathogen in Europe with an overal case fatality of 5-10%. Serogroup {{c1::B}} is the main cause of meningococcal cases in Ireland and UK. Serogroup {{c1::C}} has a marked decrease in incidence with the initiation of vaccination programme.

The african meningitis belt extends from {{c1::Senegal}} to {{c1::Ethiopia}}. Serogroup {{c1::A}} and {{c1::W}} have been the recurrent causes of epidemics for >100 yrs. Outbreaks occur every 5-12 yrs and attack rates are of 500-1000/100000 population.

Acquisition (e.g. respiratory droplets) of meningitis involves {{c1::nasal}} colonisation which can either lead to an {{c1::invasive}} infection that enters the {{c1::bloodstream}} and can then enter the {{c1::meninges}} or the {{c1::lungs}} OR it can lead to {{c1::antibody}} production which allows immunity development.

Clinical features of meningitis include high {{c1::fever}}, {{c1::headache}}, and neck {{c1::stiffness}}. Other features can include {{c1::photophobia}}, {{c1::Kernig's}} sign, seizures, altered {{c1::mental}} status, etc.
Meningococcal septicaemia presents as a rash which is indicative of {{c1::bacteremia}}. It is a {{c1::non-blanching::blanching/non-blanching}} petechial/purpuric rash.
nonblanching - blood in soft tissue

Risk factors of meningitis include {{c1::young age - infants}}, {{c1::asplenia/hyposplenism}}, {{c1::complement}} deficiencies (C3,C5-8). A C{{c1::3}} deficiency is present in various meningococcal strains while a C{{c1::5-8}} deficiency makes one prone to recurrent meningitis by serogroups W or Y. Other risk factors include {{c1::active/passive smoking}}, concurrent viral URTI esp. influenza, and an exposure risk (e.g. household contacts of index cases, living in closed quarters - military barracks, college halls, etc.

Lab exam for meningitis: A {{c1::WBC (polymorphs/lymphocytes)}} count and a protein and {{c1::Glucose}} test can be requested on the CSF. One can also perform a gram or a {{c1::ziel nielson}} stain, a culture, or {{c1::PCR}} test. Other specimens that can also be examined include and FBC, U&E, CRP, Coag, blood cultures and blood for PCR.

Antimicrobial treatment (adults) for meningitis incolve {{c1::cefotaxime/ceftriaxone}} (N.meningitidis and most strains of S.pneumoniae) (& H.influenzae, although very rare nowadays) +/- {{c1::Vancomycin}} (uncommon strains of S.pneumoniae non-susceptible to above) +/- {{c1::Ampicillin}} (listeria monocytogenes, if indicated).

When managing meningitis, a prompt diagnosis and prompt relevant investigations should be made. Initial measures include appropriate {{c1::antibiotics}}, supportive measures include {{c1::fluid}} resuscitation, ventilatory and {{c1::circulatory}} support, etc. If {{c1::steroids}} are indicated they are usually given before 1st dose of antibiotic (some recommended up to 24 hours after 1st dose antibiotic). It is also important to {{c1::notify}} Public Health and later on develop a targeted therapy based on {{c1::pathogen}} and susceptibility results.

Prevention of meningitis includes {{c1::chemoprophylaxis}} (high risk exposure) which involves finding out all close contacts of meningococcal index case (their risk of infection is increased by {{c1::400-1000}} times). These could be household contacts, kissing contacts, creche/nursery, healthcare workers, etc. {{c1::Rifampicin}} or {{c1:: Ciprofloxacin}} can be used for this purpose.

Meningococcal immunisation includes {{c1::polysaccharide}} vaccines which are poorly immunogenic and {{c1::conjugated}} vaccines which are currently in use, such as {{c1::Meningococcal C (MenC)}}, {{c1::Meningococcal B (MenB)}}, and Meningococcal ACWY vaccine (MenACWY).

The MenC conjugated vaccine is given as {{c1::3}} doses at 6 months, {{c1::13}} months (as Hib/MenC), and {{c1::12-13}} years (as MenACWY).
The MenACWY is now a routine {{c1::booster}} vaccination at {{c1::12-13}} years. These vaccines are also used for index cases and close contacts, clusters/outbreaks, at-risk groups. The MenACWY is also recommended for at-risk groups such as those with asplenia/hyposplenism, {{c1::complement}} deficiency, {{c1::down}} syndrome, {{c1::immuno}}deficiency (disease or Rx), Haemopoietic stem cellt ransplantation (HSCT) or solid organ transplantation (SOT).

The MenB vaccine capsule is {{c1::poorly}} immunogenic. Outer membrane vesicles vaccines have a {{c1::short}}-term effect only. It is a recombinant {{c1::multicomponent}} vaccine (e.g. Bexsero (Novartis)) and incoporates {{c1::4::#}} proteins. It is part of a routine childhood immunsiation schedule and is given at {{c1::2}}, {{c1::4}}, and 12 months of age. Also recommended for children who missed routine immunisation (catch up schedule), index cases, etc.

4 proteins in menB - factor H binding protein, Neisseria heparin binding antigen, Neisseria adhesion A protein, PorA P1.4

-poorly immunogenic bc too similar to human glycoproteins so difficult to develop vaccine

children.name: 09/07 Lecture 2: Antimicrobial agents: Clinical use and antimicrobial stewardship

fields:
{{c1::Antimicrobial}} agents target particular aspects of microbial replication or metabolism. They are intended to be specific for {{c1::microbes}} and not hosts (but NB: side effects). They are classified based on:
-{{c1::activity}} against type of micro-organisms
-molecular {{c1::structure}} and relatedness
-molecular {{c1::mechanism of action}}
*in practice, usually a combination of above

The antimicrobial classification based on activity against (classes of) micro-organisms includes: {{c1::antibacterial}} activity, {{c1::antiviral}} activity e.g. Candida (e.g. azoles); moulds;dermatophytes, {{c1::antiprotozoal}} activity (e.g. antimalarial and antitoxoplasmal drugs), {{c1::antihelminthic}} activity.

Antibacterial classes involve {{c1::Beta lactams}} (e.g. penicillins), {{c1::Quinolones}} (e.g. ciprofloxacin), {{c1::aminoglycosides}} (e.g. gentamicin), {{c1::macrolides}} (e.g. clarithromycin), {{c1::glycopeptides}} (e.g. vancomycin), {{c1::tetracyclines}} (e.g. doxycycline), {{c1::folate}} antagonists (e.g. trimethoprim), and others (e.g. metronidazole, linezolid, fusidic acid, etc.)

Antimicrobial agents and MOA
-{{c1::Beta lactams}} (e.g. penicillin, cephalosporin) target penicillin-{{c1::binding proteins}} and inhibit the {{c1::synthesis}} and cross-{{c1::linking}} of peptidoglycan layers of bacterial cell walls.
-{{c1::Quinolones}} (e.g. ciprofloxacin) target DNA {{c1::gyrase}} and {{c1::topoisomerase}} and inhibit DNA {{c1::replication}} and {{c1::transcription}}.
-{{c1::Aminoglycosides}} (e.g. gentamicin) target bacterial {{c1::ribosomal}} subunit and inhibit {{c1::protein}} synthesis. 
-{{c1::Folate antagonists}} (e.g. trimethoprim) target enzymes of {{c1::folate}} synthesis and inhibit {{c1::folate}} metabolism.

The Class Concept
-e.g. penicillins: benyzlpenicillin, amoxicillin, piperacillin, flucloxacillin... (common/similar molecular targets and resistant mechanism)
-Using any one penicillin is likely to impact to some degree on acquired {{c1::resistance}} to all. If a patient is allergic to one agent, there is an increased likelihood of allergy to other members within the same {{c1::class}} of agents. 
-Similar side-effects e.g. {{c1::nephrotoxicity}} in aminoglycosides.

A drug allergy is an {{c1::idiosyncratic}} reaction to an agent or class of agents (e.g. beta lactam hypersensitivity reactions).
Types of reactions include {{c1::skin rash}} (generally delayed reaction, maculopapular in nature) OR {{c1::anaphylactic-like}} reaction (which may be immediate and life threatening).
-Important to distinguish between allergic reaction to and {{c1::side-effects}} of drugs: documentation of the nature of reaction is essential.
-Many people who believe they are {{c1::allergic}} to penicillins are actually NOT: they are experiencing {{c1::side effects}} such as nausea, abdominal discomfort etc.

The exception to the {{c1::2}} ring structure of Beta lactams is {{c1::Monobactam}} which has a {{c1::1}} ring structure. Beta lactam classes include {{c1::penicillins}} (penicillin, amoxicillin, piperacillin etc.), {{c1::cephalosporins}} (cefotaxime, ceftazidime, etc.), {{c1::monobactams}} (e.g. aztreonam, etc.), {{c1::carbapenems}} (e.g. meropenem, imipenem, etc.) -broadest spectrum of activity and are useful in drug {{c1::resistant}} organisms, {{c1::beta-lactam/beta-lactamase inhibitor}} (e.g. amoxicillin-clavulanate (co-amoiclav), piperacillin-tazobactam).
cephalosporins: 1st generation (Gram+ activity) while other generations have more gram - activity.
The complicated wall structure of {{c1::Gram negative}} cells can sometimes act as a {{c1::barrier}} to antimicrobials.

Beta lactams are a {{c1::broad}} group of antimicrobial agents.
{{c1::Narrow}}-spectrum: penicillin
{{c1::broad}} spectrum: cephalosporins, co-amoxiclav, piperacillin-tazobactam, carbapenems.
{{c1::moderate}}-spectrum: amoxicillin, piperacillin

-They are widely used in clinical infections including {{c1::pneumonia}} (amoxicillin, co-amoxiclav, cephalosporins), {{c1::meningitis}} (penicillin, cefotaxime/ceftriaxone), UTIs (co-amoxiclav, ceftriaxone), {{c1::skin}} infections (flucloxacillin, penicillin), intra-abdominal infetions (co-amoxiclav, cephalosporins), etc.

Erythromycin, Clarithromycin, azithromycin are {{c1::macrolides}} that have reasonable activity against some Gram {{c1::positive}} organisms (e.g. S. aureus, S. pneumoniae, atypical organisms e.g. Legionella, Mycoplasma). They are useful in {{c1::respiratory tract}} infections; some infections by S. aureus in cases of {{c1::penicillin}}-allergy.

Ciprofloxacin, levofloxacin, etc. are {{c1::Quinolones}} that are {{c1::broad}} spectrum against Gram-{{c1::negative}} organisms e.g. E.coli, Klebsiella. Some have activity against Streptococcus e.g. levofloxacin (S.pneumoniae). They are useful in {{c1::intra-abdominal}} infections, {{c1::urinary tract}} infections, levofloxacin in {{c1::respiratory}} tract infections. Potential side effects include {{c1::clostridium difficile}} infection, etc.

Gentamicin, amikacin, tobramycin, etc. are {{c1::aminoglycosides}} that have activity against Gram-{{c1::negative}} organisms. They are usually used in conjunction with other agents (e.g. beta lactam) for serious infections e.g. bloodstream infections, {{c1::sepsis}}, {{c1::UTI}} or LRTI.
They have significant potential for toxicity: {{c1::nephrotoxicity}} (e.g. gentamicin, amikacin) or {{c1::oto}}toxicity (amikacin).

When considering antimicrobial use, it is important to look at whether an {{c1::infection}} is present (clinical evidence vs lab results), the {{c1::site}} of infection (e.g. antimicrobials may have difficulty entering CNS), whether its a {{c1::bacterial}} or {{c1::viral}} infection, and if alternative measures can be taken to avoid antimicrobials (e.g. abscess drainage, wound toilet, oral rehydration for mild UTI, etc.). Appropriate antimicrobial therapy requires a look at the {{c1::dosage}} of drugs, {{c1::route}} of administration, {{c1::duration}} of therapy, and choice of {{c1::agent}}. It is important to switch from IV to {{c1:Oral}} Rx as early as possible.

When prescribing antimicrobials, it is important to start smart, then focus. Starting smart involves
-considering the {{c1::site}} of infection, and the most likely and important {{c1::pathogens}}; take relevant cultures.
-the local antimicrobial {{c1::susceptibility}} patterns of the pathogens
-international/national/local guidelines
-any specific {{c1::contra}}-indications or considerations (allergies, renal failure..)
-patient's specific {{c1::history}} (possibly drug-resistant organisms?)

Focus involves the
-identification of causative {{c1::pathogen}} (e.g. cultures, PCR)
-antimicrobial {{c1::susceptibility}} results of the pathogen
-considering whether modification of {{c1::empiric}} therapy is indicated
(Aim: focused therapy targeting the pathogen using {{c1::narrow}} spectrum agents if feasible).
**SEE Example in Antimicrobial lecture

Antimicrobial use in animals
Ciprofloxacin is not used in animals but {{c1::enrofloxacin}} is used instead since it is absorbed and metabolised to ciprofloxacin.
-Fluoroquinolones include Ofloxacin, {{c1::ciprofloxacin}}, {{c1::enrofloxacin}}, {{c1::levofloacin}}, moxifloxacin, etc. The {{c1::class}} concept can be applied here as well since reduced susceptibility to one may imply reduced susceptibility to all.
Antimicrobial resistant organisms in food due to use in animals may be a problem.

Antimicrobials are widely available legally over the counter. Counterfeit antimicrobials can also be purchased and this can result in the content being much less than marked and the medication being of {{c1::sub-therapeutic}} levels - leads to a greater risk of {{c1::resistance}}.

Scalp lacerations easily occur due to tight apposition of the scalp to the {{c1::calvarium}}. As there is free communication between the scalp and face vessels to the veins of the {{c1::meninges}}, there is a danger of {{c1::meningitis}} (especially when there's a skull fracture!)

If a patient has a skull fracture, you should look for bleeding from the {{c1::ears}} or into the {{c1::orbit}}. A leak of CSF from the nose is due to injury to the {{c1::ethmoid}} bone. A "black eye" means bleeding into the eye socket due to {{c1::orbital}} injury.

This image represents inhalation of blood from injury to the {{c1::base}} of the skull.


This image represents injury to the {{c1::orbital plate}}.
Injuries on the vertex of the skull should always raise suspicion of {{c1::assault}}.
(Unusual to fall on top of head)

{{c1::Concussion}} is a transient paralytic state due to head injury which is of {{c1::instantaneous}} onset, does not show any evidence of structural cerebral injury and is always followed by {{c1::amnesia}} from the actual moment of the accident. The duration of loss of {{c1::consciousness}} is usually a guide to the degree of cerebral pathology.

- extremely common
- cause controversial: some mechanical process temporarily distupts the function, if not necessarily the structure, of the brain.
Chronic {{c1::Traumatic}} {{c1::Encephalopathy}} is a sports-related neurological injury due to repeated bouts of concussion, especially repetitive concussion, often mild!
Contact (collision) sports: boxing, football (NFL). Others include wrestling, karate, rugby, parachuting. Also iraq war soldiers.

Chronic Traumatic encephalopathy includes clinical features such as {{c1::memory}} disturbances, behavioural and {{c1::personality}} changes, {{c1::parkin}}sonism, speech and gait abnormalities (depends on area affected).
Remember "second impact syndrome"

Chronic Traumatic Encephalopathy includes pathological features such as {{c1::atrophy}} of cerebral hemispheres, medial temporal lobe, {{c1::thalamus}}, {{c1::mammilary}} bodies and brainstem with ventricular {{c1::dilatation}}.

Treatment: decrease no. of concussive episodes, limit exposure to trauma with severe penalties for deliberate blows to the head, adherence to strict return to play guidelines, avoid second concussive episode at all costs within weeks of the first, give up the sport.

{{c1::Diffuse axonal injury}} is primarily a non-impact rotational acceleration-deceleration phenomenon. Most significant factor is probably deformation by {{c1::stretching}}. Gross pathology {{c1::is not::is/is not}} seen.Brain should be histologically examined post {{c1::10-14::#}} days fixation. {{c1::"Retraction globes"}} can be seen on microscopy due to axonal disruption. It is the most common cause of longterm {{c1::morbidity}} from head injury.
The meninges include the {{c1::dura}}, {{c1::arachnoid}},and {{c1::pia}} mater.

{{c1::Subarachnoid}} haemorrhage is when there is blood between the arachnoid and pia mater (Trauma, ruptured berry aneurysm).{{c1::Extradural}} haemorrhage is when there is blood between the skull and the dura mater (injury to temporal bone). {{c1::Subdural}} haemorrhage is when there is blood between the dura and arachnoid mater (Simple fall - often in {{c1::elderly}} people). {{c1::Intracerebral}} haemorrhage is due to hypertension and sometimes trauma.
Know intracranial (broad category of all haemorrhages) vs intracerebral difference

Extradural haemorrhage is trauma to the {{c1::squamous temporal::2 words}} bone. May be no significant trauma to the underlying brain so can have good prognosis if detected early. Clinical presentation of EDH includes trauma (to side of head) which leads to a {{c1::concusssion}} followed by a {{c1::lucid}} interval and then a loss of {{c1::consciousness}}. This can be followed by coma/death.

Pathologically, EDH can present with injury of thin {{c1::temporal}} bone with tearing of the middle {{c1::meningeal}} artery. It also presents with {{c1::bleeding}} with separation of dura from bone, usuall  over 6-12 hours. Lastly, it can present with accumulation of a large {{c1::haematoma}} outside the dura - leading to compression of the adjacent cerebral hemisphere.

-injury to meningeal NOT temporal artery
-VERY THIN temporal bone

Haematoma outside dura


Injury to temporal bone below

EDH
A subdural haemorrhage/haematoma (SDH) is often a minor head trauma in {{c1::elderly}} patients with often no skull injury. It may be associated with {{c1::child abuse}} in infants.

SDH pathology presents with the tearing of {{c1::bridging}} veins as they enter the superior sagittal sinus, due to {{c1::shearing}} force on veins (often coming from a small atrophic brain) which is oscillating due to minor head trauma. It is associated with {{c1::slow::fast/slow}} venous bleeding. In chronic SDH, {{c1::granulation}} tissue grows into the hematoma and tries to organize and remove it. This tissue originates from the {{c1::dura}} rather than the brain.

Acute traumatic subarachnoid haemorrhage (SAH) can have trauma to {{c1::Circle of Willis}} vessels. Basal subarachnoid haemorrhage has trauma to {{c1::vertebral}} arteries. These arteries are vulnerable when they enter the foramen {{c1::magnum}}.
Vertebral artery trauma - typically caused by blunt force to the side of the neck behind the ear ("karate chop" - type blow).
Non traumatic SAH are associated with ruptured {{c1::berry}} aneurysms - 5-10mm in diameter. These are {{c1::saccular}} type of aneurysms and are usually located at {{c1::bifurcations}} of arteries.

-Most common locations: Anterior and posterior communicating arteries, middle cerebral artery
-Congenital
-Non CNS condition related to berry aneurysms - adult PCKD
Ruptured {{c1::berry aneurysm}} clinically presents with a sudden onset of the "worst headache of my life". May have history of preceding, less severe, headaches: {{c1::herald}} bleeds.
herald bleed - episode of haemorrhage, often accompanied by abdominal pain (may precede a catastrophic haemorrhage).
A rarer cause of SAH is {{c1::vascular malformation}}.

With hypertension, intracerebral haemorrhages tend to be in the {{c1::thalamus}}, external capsule, pons and {{c1::cerebellum}}, and are more often {{c1::occipital}} than frontal or temporal. With trauma, intracerebral haemorrhage may be caused by {{c1::coup}} or {{c1::contrecoup}} mechanisms and may be situated anywhere within the hemispheres.
can sometimes be difficult to determine if a head injury was responsible for an intracerebral haemorrhage or if an intracerebral haemorrhage led to a fall which caused a head injury.

children.name: 08/31 Lecture 2: space occupying lesions and raised ICP

fields: {{c1::Adult::Adult/Child}} brain tumours are supra-tentorial and {{c1::childhood::Adult/Child}} brain tumours are infra-tentorial.
even benign brain tumours may lead to serious clinical deficits and poor prognosis. Crtiical regions - lethal consequences.
Malignant tumours {{c1::rarely::commonly/rarely}} metastasize outside CNS.
Glial CNS tumours include {{c1::astrocytoma}} (infiltrating vs noninfiltrating), {{c1::oligodendroglioma}}, {{c1::ependymoma}}.
Primary CNS tumours

Non-Glial tumours include {{c1::neuronal}} tumours, {{c1::meningioma}}, {{c1::pituitary}} adenoma,  and {{c1::Schwannoma}} (acoustic neuroma). Other primary CNS tumours could include medulloblastoma and {{c1::hemangioblastoma}}.
Primary CNS tumours

Infiltrating {{c1::astrocytomas}} are glial tumours that make up 80% of adult primary brain tumours. The most common location is the {{c1::cerebral hemisphere}}. Symptoms can include {{c1::seizures}}, headaches, and {{c1::focal}} neurological deficits. Often not possible to {{c1::resect}} infiltrative astrocytomas completely without compromising neurologic function.
Spectrum of differentiation: diffuse astrocytoma (grade II), anaplastic astrocytoma (grade III), glioblastoma multiforme (grade IV)

{{c1::Glioblastoma multiforme}} is a glial tumour that is a grade IV astrocytoma. Histological features include {{c1::necrosis}}, {{c1::vascular}} proliferation, {{c1::palisading}} of nuclei (triad of features). It has very {{c1::poor::good/poor}} prognosis.
palisading - in a line

A {{c1::pilocytic astrocytoma}} is a glial tumour that is a non-infiltrating grade I astrocytoma. It is accompanied by relatively {{c1::benign}} behavior in both children and young adults and may be cured by {{c1::resection}}.

{{c1::Oligodendrogliomas}} are glial tumours that are histologically known for their delicate capillary network of "chicken wire vessels". Their cells have a perinuclear {{c1::halo}} ("fried egg appearance). Tumours of this type that show {{c1::chromosome 1p/19q}} co-deletion have been found to be especially chemosensitive.
{{c1::Ependymomas}} are glial tumours that arise next to ependyma-lined ventricular system.
{{c1::Ganglioglioma}} is the most common type of neuronal (non-glial) tumour.

{{c1::Meningiomas}} are non-glial tumours that are benign and found in adults. They are attached to the dura and arise from {{c1::meningoendothelial}} cells of arachnoid. They are associated with mutations in the {{c1::PTEN}} tumour suppressor gene.
Meningiomas have a {{c1::whorled}} pattern of meningothelial cells. {{c1::Psammomatous}} calcification is also a common histological feature.
{{c1::Acoustic neuroma}} is a non-glial tumour that is benign and arises from Schwann cells of CNVIII. It is association with {{c1::neurofibromatosis::genetic condition}}.

{{c1::Medulloblastoma}} is a type of PNET (primitive neuroectodermal tumour) found in children. It is usually found in the {{c1::cerebellum}} of the brain and may be associated with {{c1::MYC}} amplification in more aggressive tumours. A "small round blue cell tumour".
A hemangioblastoma is a tumour found in the {{c1::cerebellum}} of the brain and is associated with {{c1::Von-Hippel-Lindau}} genetic syndrome.
A primary CNS lymphoma is the most common CNS tumour in {{c1::immunocompromised}} individuals. It is aggressive and has a {{c1::poor}} response to chemotherapy compared with peripheral lymphomas.

{{c1::Metastatic}} tumours are the most common brain tumours seen in community hospitals. They are typically located at the {{c1::grey-white}} matter junction and can include {{c1::lung}}, breast, melanoma, {{c1::kidney}}, GIT, choriocarcinoma tumours.
Raised ICP can cause cerebral {{c1::edema}}, {{c1::hydrocephalus}}, and {{c1::herniation}}.

Cerebral edema is vasogenic and is caused by {{c1::blood-brain-barrier}} disruption and increased {{c1::vascular permeability}} (allowing fluid to shift from the intravascular compartment to the intercellular spaces of the brain). It is also {{c1::cytotoxic}} and causes an increase in ICF secondary to neuronal, glial or endothelial cell membrane injury (e.g. in someone with a generalised hypoxic/ischaemic insult or with metabolic damage).

{{c1::Cerebral edema}} is extremely common after a substantial head injury, esp. in children. It may be related to {{c1::DAI}} and to concussion. Brain weight matter may increase by 100g, mainly in the {{c1::white}} matter. It also may be the only intracranial abnormality found at autopsy after a substantial head injury as occurred.
{{c1::Hydrocephalus}} is the accumulation of excessive CSF within the ventricular system. It develops in infancy before closure of the {{c1::cranial sutures}}, there is enlargement of the head.

Raised ICP and herniation can occur due to generalized {{c1::cerebral edema}} or due to focal {{c1::lesion}} (e.g. haemorrhage, tumour, abscess). If brain expansion is severe enough, {{c1::herniation}} will occur.
{{c1::Subfalcine (cingulate)}} herniation is when the cingulate gyrus gets displaced under the falx cerebri.
Types of herniation
{{c1::Transtentorial}} herniation is when the medial aspect of the temporal lobe is compressed against the free margin of the tentorium.
{{c1::Tonsillar}} herniation is the displacement of the cerebellar tonsils through the foramen magnum - this leads to {{c1::coning}}.

 matter edema.

This image is of an {{c1::astrocytoma::glial tumour}}  with {{c1::white}} matter edema and compression of the {{c1::lateral ventricle}}.

This image shows herniation of the {{c1::temporal lobe}}.


This image shows {{c1::tonsillar::type}} herniation.

This image shows {{c1::duret}} haemorrhages (secondary brain haemorrhages). These often accompany progressive {{c1::tentorial}} herniation. It is believed to be due to distortion or tearing of {{c1::penetrating}} veins and arteries supplying the upper brainstem.

Causes of cerebral edema (increased ICP) include brain {{c1::haemorrhages}}, brain {{c1::tumours}}, {{c1::diffuse axonal injury}}, and {{c1::hypoxic}} injury (e.g. cardiac arrest, stroke, asphyxial deaths, CO poisoning).

{{c1::Stroke}} is a cerebrovascular accident or CVA. It is a sudden neurologic event of {{c1::vascular}} origin, with clinical symptoms and signs which last more than {{c1::24}} hours or may lead to death.

Stroke aetiology can be {{c1::ischaemic}} or {{c1::haemorrhagic}}. A {{c1::transient ischaemic attack (TIA/mini stroke)}} is a neurologic event of vascular origin in which symptoms and signs last for <24 hours (in most cases 1-2 hours).

Stroke is the {{c1::second}} most common cause of mortality worldwide and the {{c1::third}} most common cause of disability. It involves a spectrum of disorders including {{c1::TIA}} ( <24 hours effect), {{c1::Reversible Ischemic Neurologic Deficit -RIND}} (>24 hours but resolves), partial non-progressing stroke, {{c1::progressing}} stroke (stroke in evolution), and complete stroke (completely irreversible).

Risk factors for stroke include {{c1::hypertension}}, {{c1::smoking}}, {{c1::heart disease and impaired cardiac function}} (AR such as AF; LVH; valvular disease), hyper{{c1::lipidemia}}, diabetes, and {{c1::obesity}}.

Stroke in patients <50 years could be due to {{c1::vessel}} wall disease, vasculitis, {{c1::aortic dissection}}, {{c1::sickle cell}} anemia, {{c1::anti-phospholipid}} syndrome OR heart problems including {{c1::valve}} prolapse, {{c1::congenital heart}} disease, patent {{c1::foramen ovale}} or {{c1::ventricular}} septal defect (paradoxical embolism). It can also be due to oral contraceptives.
APL syndrome - disorder of the immune system that causes an increased risk of blood clots. (Greater ris of DVT, etc.)
Virchows triad involves {{c1::hypercoagulability}}, {{c1::endothelial injury}}, and {{c1::stasis of blood flow}}.
{{c1::Ischaemic}} strokes involve a problem with the blood flow/O2 while {{c1::Haemorrhagic}} strokes involve a bleed from a vessel/aneurysm within the brain.

Focal cerebral ischemia follows {{c1::reduction/cessation}} of blood flow to a {{c1::localised}} area of the brain due to arterial occlusion or {{c1::hypoperfusion}} (embolisation from distant source/in situ thrombosis/vasculitis). If this is sustained it can lead to an {{c1::infarction}}. There is little, if any, {{c1::collateral}} blood flow for the deep penetrating cerebral vessels supplying structures such as thalamus, basal ganglia and deep white matter.

20% of cerebral infarcts are {{c1::haemorrhagic}} while 80% are {{c1::non-haemorrhagic (ischaemic)}}. It is important to differentiate because treatment is completely different. Often initially non-haemorrhagic. Can get secondary haemorrhage due to {{c1::ischaemia-reperfusion}} injury. Clinical features depend on the anatomic region affected; classical signs include {{c1::unilateral}} facial weakness or {{c1::drooping}}, unilateral {{c1::limb}} weakness, and {{c1::slurred}} speech. (FAST.)
Non-haemorrhagic (ischaemic) stroke can be due to {{c1::thrombosis}}, {{c1::embolism (most common and usually thromboembolism)}}, or systemic {{c1::hypoperfusion}}.

A thrombus is when a {{c1::clot}} forms i.e. a solid mass forms from liquid blood (remember Virchows triad). An {{c1::embolus}} is anything including a thrombus that travels through the vasculature that can cause a blockage.

An {{c1::embolic}} ischaemic stroke can occur due to cardiac mural thrombi. {{c1::Thromboemboli}} arising from arteries (esp carotids) predisposes you to cardiac mural thrombi. These can also be of other material such as fat, {{c1::air}}, tumour.
Cardiac mural thrombus\

Both small and large vessel disease can cause {{c1::Thrombotic}} ischaemic stroke. Large vessel disease can be {{c1::extracranial}} which includes the common and internal carotids, or {{c1::intracranial}} which includes the circle of willis and proximal branches.{{c1::Atherosclerosis}}, vasculitis, and {{c1::dissection}} can all cause large vessel disease. Small vessel disease is {{c1::intracranial}} which includes small penetrating arteries arising from distal vertebral artery, basilar artery, MCA, circle of Willis. Changes could be due to {{c1::hypertension}} (arteriolar sclerosis, fibrinoid degeneration), or {{c1::atheroma}}.
Atherogenesis: another word for large vessel disease

Ischaemia can be induced through systemic {{c1::hypoperfusion}}. This can lead to diffuse ischaemic/hypoxic {{c1::encephalopathy}}. It causes global cerebral ischaemia. Signs would be diffuse, non-{{c1::focal}}, and {{c1::bilateral}}. It occurs when there is a generalised reduction in cerebral {{c1::perfusion}} (cardiac arrest, shock, severe hypotension). {{c1::Watershed}} infarcts are usually seen after hypotensive episodes; occur at border zones between arterial territories.

-Most sensitive neurones in the brain: pyramidal layer of hippocampus, cerebellar purkinje cells, pyramidal neurones in cerebral cortex.

-watershed infarcts (border zone infarcts) occur at the border between cerebral vascular terrritories where the tissue is furthest from arterial supply and thus most vulnerable to reductions in perfusion.

Macroscopic morphology of cerebral ischaemia involves {{c1::cerebral oedema}}, poor demarcation of {{c1::grey and white matter}}. Microscopic changes involve:
12-24 hrs: "{{c1::red::colour}} dead neurones" then infiltration by {{c1::neutrophils}}.
24 hours - 2 weeks: {{c1::necrosis}}, {{c1::macrophage}} influx, {{c1::vascular}} proliferation, reactive gliosis.
>2 weeks: loss of normal CNS artchitecture with {{c1::gliosis}}.
brain: liquefactive necrosis
This image represents {{c1::cerebral edema}} and you can observe the {{c1::widened}} gyri and {{c1::flattened}} sulci.

In hypertensive cerebrovascular disease, the most important effects of HTN on the brain include {{c1::lacunar}} infarcts, {{c1::slit}} haemorrhages, {{c1::hypertensive encephalopathy::2 words}}, and intracerebral haemorrhage/haemorrhagic stroke.

In hypertensive cerebrovascular disease, HTN affects the {{c1::deep}} penetrating arteries and arterioles that supply the {{c1::basal ganglia}} and hemispheric white matter as well as the brain stem. Vessels develop {{c1::arteriolar sclerosis}} and may become occluded (c.f. the systemic vessels of people with HTN). Single/multiple small cavitary infarcts called {{c1::lacunes}} can develop (lakelike spaces).

In hypertensive cerebrovascular disease, rupture of small-calibre penetrating vessels and development of small haemorrhages can occur. In time, these resolve and leave behind {{c1::slit hamemorrhages}} surrounded by {{c1::brown::colour}}-ish discolouration.

{{c1::Hypertensive encephalopathy}} is a clinicopathological syndrome part of hypertensive cerebrovascular disease that arrises in the setting of malignant HTN. It involves {{c1::diffuse}} cerebral dysfunction: headaches, {{c1::confusion}}, vomiting, convulsions and can lead to {{c1::coma}}. This syndrome is a MEDICAL EMERGENCY.

In hypertensive cerebrovascular disease, {{c1::intracerebral haemorrhages}} typically occur in deep white matter or deep grey matter or brainstem and cerebellum. {{c1::Charcot-Bouchard}} microaneurysms can also occur.
The arrow is pointing to a {{c1::berry aneurysm}}.
A non-CNS disorder associated with berry aneurysms is {{c1::adult Polycystic kidney disease (PCKD)}}.

{{c1::Coeliac disease}} is the most ommon form of malabsorption in Ireland and is based on the Dutch word {{c1::sprue}}. It is an immune-mediated enteropathy triggered by the ingestion of {{c1::gluten}}-containing cereals, such as wheat, rye or barley, in {{c1::genetically}} predisposed individuals. This disease affects {{c1::1}}% of the population around the world.

Clinical features of coeliac disease include abdominal {{c1::pain}} and {{c1::distension}}, {{c1::anorexia}}, {{c1::diarrhoea}} or constipation, failure to thrive in children, {{c1::weight loss}}, and fatigue. This disease most commonly occurs in adults of {{c1::30-60}} years of age.

Coeliac disease also has extraintestinal manifestations which include {{c1::arthritis/joint pain}}, osteoporosis, {{c1::autoimmune thyroid disease}}, {{c1::hypo}}splenism (unknown mechanism), {{c1::iron-deficiency}} anemia, short {{c1::stature}} and {{c1::pubertal}} delay in children, dermatitis {{c1::herpetiformis}} and lymphocytic {{c1::gastritis}} or {{c1::colitis}}.

Top: Dermatitis herpetiformis (IgA)
Bottom: Lymphocytic gastritis/colitis
The pathogenesis of coeliac disease involves the interaction between {{c1::gluten}} and {{c1::immune}}, {{c1::genetic}} and environmental factors.

Pathogenesis: The role of gluten in Coeliac disease - Undigested {{c1::gliadin}} molecules are resistant to degradation by {{c1::proteases}} in the intestine and thus remain in the lumen after ingestion. They pass through the epithelial barrier of the intestine, possibly during {{c1::infections}} or when there is an increase in intestinal {{c1::permeability}}, and interact with {{c1::APCs}} in the lamina propria.
Gliadin: subcomponent of gluten

Pathogenesis: Mucosal immune responses - In patients with coeliac disease, immune reponses to {{c1::gliadin}} fractions promote an {{c1::inflammatory}} reaction.
Adaptive immune responses are mediated by {{c1::gliadin}}-reactive CD{{c1::4}}+ T Cells, which produce proinflammatory cytokines. {{c1::Tissue transglutaminase (TTG)}} is an intestinal enzyme that deamidates gliadin peptides, increasing their {{c1::immunogenicity}} which leads to an inflammatory cascade.
Innate immune response occurs when enterocytes increase expression of {{c1::IL15}}, which activates intraepithelial lymphocytes (IELs). These activated IELs become {{c1::cytotoxic}} and damage enterocytes.
Immunogenicity - ability to provoke an immune response.

Pathogenesis: Genetic Factors - These involve {{c1::HLADQ2}} (90% of the time, {{c1::HLADQ8}} (5% of the time), and other non-{{c1::HLA}} genes that may influence susceptibility (influence uncertain) - the rest of the 5% of the time.

Pathogenesis: environmental factors - ingestion of gluten at less than {{c1::4}} months of age is associated with increased risk of coeliac disease. {{c1::Rotavirus}} infection may also be associated with an increased risk.

When performing serological tests for Coeliac Disease, it is important to check the serum {{c1::IgA}} for deficiency. Since the test has high {{c1::specificity}} and {{c1::sensitivity}}, it can also confirm {{c1::false positives}}.

To diagnose coeliac disease, a {{c1::duodenal (D2)}} biopsy should be done to observe histological features.


In the abnormal mucosa, {{c1::villous}} atrophy, crypt {{c1::hyperplasia}}, increased {{c1::plasma cells}} in the lamina propria can all be observed.
This image represents increased {{c1::IELs (Intraepithelial lymphocytes)}} as a result of the mucosal immune response. Normally, there should only be 1 lymphocyte per {{c1::5}} cells.

In adults, coeliac disease most commonly presents between ages of {{c1::30-60}}. {{c1::Silent}} coeliac disease has positive TTG serology and villous atrophy without symptoms. {{c1::Latent}} coeliac disease has positive TTG serology without villous atrophy (may have increased IELs).

Complications of coeliac disease include {{c1::refractory}} coeliac disease, {{c1::enteropathy-associated T cell lymphoma (EATL)}} (Bad prognosis), and increased risk of {{c1::small bowel}} adenocarcinoma.
(EATL: T cell more progressive than B cell)

Refractory coeliac disease is a complication of coeliac disease that involves persistent or recurrent {{c1::malabsorptive}} symptoms and signs despite adherence to a gluten-free diet for >{{c1::12}} months.
Type 1 versus Type 2

Type 1 refractory coeliac disease involves {{c1::68-80}}% of all refractory coeliac disease cases. Many cases thought to relate to {{c1::surreptitious/secret}} ingestion of gluten causing sustained {{c1::inflammation}}; a minority of cases thought to relate to transition to an {{c1::autoimmune}} state. It also involves {{c1::Polyclonal}} expansion of T cells; risk of developing {{c1::EATL}} is low (3-14% at 4-6 years).

Type 2 refractory coeliac disease involves {{c1::monoclonal}} expansion of T cells and there is a risk of developing {{c1::EATL}} (60% at 5 years). IELs are usually {{c1::negative}} for CD8 and also show variable {{c1::down}}regulation or loss of other T cell antigens. Type 2 is usually accompanied by severe {{c1::villous atrophy::histological feature}} and there are usually severe symptoms and features of {{c1::malnourishment}} (e.g. low BMI). One can also get systemic dissemination of aberrant {{c1::IELs)}}.

EATL is a coeliac disease complication that develops in the {{c1::jejunum}} or {{c1::ileum}}. Often, patients have a history of {{c1::refractory coeliac disease}}: some patients have no history of coeliac disease. EATL presents with {{c1::abdominal pain}} and, not infrequently, intestinal {{c1::perforation}}; usually <{{c1::3}} month history of symptoms. It is often a multifocal disease. Ocassionally has extra-{{c1::gastrointestinal}} sites (e.g. skin, lymph nodes, spleen).

EATL also has a wide range of cytological appearances, most commonly {{c1::pleomorphic}} medium to large-sized cells. Usually see features of coeliac disease in adjacent uninvolved intestinal mucosa. Usually retains CD{{c1::3}}, with an aberrant loss of CD{{c1::4}}, CD{{c1::5}}, and CD{{c1::8}}. Often expression of CD {{c1::30}} indicates a case of Type 2 refractory coeliac disease progression to EATL.

Prognosis of EATL is {{c1::poor}} (multifocal disease, high rate intestinal recurrence); median survival is {{c1::7 months}}. Better outcomes for patients with intensive {{c1::chemotherapy}} and autologous {{c1::stem cell}} transplant.
Other forms of malabsorption involve {{c1::tropical}} sprue, {{c1::collagenous}} sprue, and {{c1::disaccharidase}} (lactase) deficiency.

Must see {{c1::positive}} serology and characteristic histological featuers on {{c1::duodenal}} biopsy for diagnosis of coeliac disease. A lifelong {{c1::gluten}}-free diet is required and the most serious complication is {{c1::EATL}}.

4. Cereal that does not contain gluten - {{c1::g}}

The inner layer or lining of the esophagus is the {{c1::mucosa}}. This is {{c1::moist}} in texture so that food can pass to the stomach. The sub-mucosa layer of the esophagus makes {{c1::mucus}} which keeps the oesophagus {{c1::hydrated}}.
The {{c1::muscle}} layer of the esophagus uses the muscles to push the food down to the stomach.
Lastly, the {{c1::outer}} layer of the esophagus covers the esophagus.

The mucosa layer of the oesophagus consists of the {{c1::epithelium}}, {{c1::lamina propria}}, and muscularis mucosa. Directly underneath this layer, lies the {{c1::submucosa}} layer, followed by the {{c1::muscularis propria}} layer.

{{c1::Oesophagitis}} is a general term for inflammation, irritation or swelling of the oesophagus. It may damage the tissues of the oesophagus. This clinically presents with a high degree of specificity - including features of {{c1::dysphagia}}, {{c1::heartburn}}, and odynophagia. It requires a differential diagnosis which could include {{c1::chest pain}}, functional {{c1::dyspepsia}}, or pericarditis.

Dysphagia is a clinical feature of oesophagitis which involves difficulty in {{c1::swallowing}}. This requires further investigation as there is also a concern for peptic {{c1::stricture}} or {{c1::adeno}}carcinoma.

Heartburn is a clinical feature of oesophagitis which involves episodic sub{{c1::sternal}} pain - worse after {{c1::meals}} and on {{c1::reclining::position}} and relieved, at least temporarily, by {{c1::antacids}} (this feature is important bc it links pain with {{c1::acidity}}). This often presents as a burning discomfort which commonly radiates toward the {{c1::mouth}} and is frequently accompanied by complaints of a {{c1::bitter}} taste in the mouth (regurgitation) or a welling up in the mouth of a {{c1::salty}} tasting (salivary derived) fluid. If the substernal pain is relieved by {{c1::antacids}} and recurs at least {{c1::once}} per week over an extended period - this could be a diagnosis for GERD.

Odynophagia is a clinical feature of oesophagitis which involves {{c1::painful}} swallowing and implies an acute and {{c1::severe}} form of esophagitis, typically with mucosal {{c1::ulceration}}. It is experienced substernally as an {{c1::aching}} or {{c1::stabbing}} pain that is aggravated by the act of swallowing (even saliva). Common in esophagitis caused by {{c1::infection}}, radiation, and {{c1::pills}}, but rare in esophagitis caused by reflux.

For most upper gastrointeestinal lesions, an {{c1::upper endoscopy}} can be used because it has a sensitivity of 90% and specificity of nearly 100%. It allows for {{c1::direct}} visualisation and for a more accurate and sensitive evaluation of {{c1::mucosal lesions}}. It can also be used to perform {{c1::therapeutic}} interventions and {{c1::biopsy}} specimens from superficial lesions.
Types of oesophagitis involve {{c1::lacerations}}, {{c1::chemical}}, {{c1::infectious}}, {{c1::eosinophilic}}, reflux, and {{c1::Barrett's}} Oesophagitis.

Mallory Weiss Tears are longitudinal {{c1::lacerations}} near the {{c1::gastroesophageal}} junction. They are associated with {{c1::alcoholic binges}} and are most likely due to {{c1::mechanical}} trauma in conjunction with failure of gastroesophageal muscular {{c1::relaxation}}. Mucosal defect of varying range - usually involves the {{c1::mucosa}} and/or {{c1::submucosa}}. Supportive therapy is usually sufficient. Complications can involve mild/moderate {{c1::haemorrhage}}, rarely rupture (if they do - known as Boerhaave syndrome).
alcholic binges - projectile vomiting

Chemical oeosophagitis is when the stratified {{c1::squamous}} mucosa is damaged by alcohol, {{c1::corrosive acids}} or alkalis, heavy {{c1::smoking}}, or {{c1::hot}} fluids. High risk for children and household chemicals. If insufficient fluid is taken with {{c1::pills}}, it can result in {{c1::pill}} induced oesophagitis.
Infectious oesophagitis is most commonly seen in {{c1::immunocompromised}} patients. It can involve the {{c1::Candida}} virus, {{c1::HSV}} virus, or the CMV.

{{c1::Eosinophilic}} oesophagitis is an uncommon (but becoming more common), immunologically mediated entity (food allergy). Histologically, characterised by large numbers of intraepithelial {{c1::eosinophils}}. Acid reflux {{c1::is not::is/is not}} a common cause, with PPIs {{c1::rarely::usually/rarely}} providing relief. Can manifest as chest pain or heartburn, but {{c1:: solid food dysphagia}} and food {{c1::impaction}} are characterisitic. Can also manifest as feeing intolerance or {{c1::GERD}} like symptoms in children.

Diagnostic criteria for eosinophilic oesophagitis include endoscopic findings of rings, longitudinal {{c1::furrows}}, exudates, {{c1::oedema}}, {{c1::strictures}}, white {{c1::plaques}}, microabscesses, etc. Concomitant {{c1::atopic}} conditions should increase suspicion for EoE.
Some conditions associated with esophageal esoinophilia involve eosinophilic {{c1::gastritis}}, {{c1::GERD}}, {{c1::achalasia}}, and many more.
(don't really need to know all)

Abnormal histological features seen with eosinophilic oesophagitis include {{c1::intraepithelial}} eosinophils, {{c1::dilated}} intercellular spaces, and a {{c1::thickened (hyperplasia)}} basal layer.
Eosinophilic oesophagitis

Eosinophilic Oesophagitis treatment involves the removal of an {{c1::allergic}} reaction source. {{c1::PPI}} may be of limited use in a small number of patients. Topical steroids such as {{c1::fluticasone}} or {{c1::budesonide}}. May require {{c1::dilation}} treatments if there are strictures.
(don't really need to focus on)

{{c1::GERD}} is a condition in which the gastric or duodenal contents (food or liquid) leak backwards from the stomach into the oesophagus. This irritates the oesophagus, causing {{c1::heartburn}} and other symptoms. It is also known as {{c1::peptic}} oesophagitis. When the sphincter of muscle fibres called the {{c1::lower oesophageal sphincter (LES)}} doesn't close well, food, liquid, and stomach acid can leak back into the oesophagus.

About {{c1::44}}% of the adult population have heartburn at least once a month. {{c1::14}}% of adults have symptoms weekly. {{c1::7}}% have symptoms daily. Long term consequences are {{c1::bleeding}} (almost never massive), stricture, {{c1::Barrett's}} esophagus with possible {{c1::Barrett ulcer}}.

Risk factors for GERD involve {{c1::hiatal}} hernia, {{c1::pregnancy}}, scleroderma, {{c1::obesity}}, smoking, {{c1::alcohol}}, certain medicines (anticholinergics, B blockers, bronchodilators, dopamine, sedatives/anxiety meds, tricyclic antidepressants e.a. clomipramine), and an inverse association with {{c1::H.pylori}} infection.

GERD pathophysiology involves an abnormal {{c1::Lower esophageal sphincter}}. This can be {{c1::functional}} (frequent transient relaxation) or {{c1::mechanical}} (hypotensive LES). Certain things such as {{c1::foods}} (coffee,alcohol), {{c1::medications}} (eg calcium channel blockers), or {{c1::location (e.g. hiatal hernia)}} can decrease the pressure of the LES. Increased {{c1::abdominal pressure}} caused by things such as obesity, pregnancy, or increased gastric volume can also cause GERD.

The primary barrier to {{c1::gastroesophageal}} reflux is the lower esophageal sphincter. The LES normally works in conjunction with the {{c1::diaphragm}}. If the barrier is disrupted, acid goes from the stomach to the {{c1::esophagus}}.

When performing a diagnostic evaluation of GERD, use an {{c1::upper endoscopy}} to look for erosions, {{c1::ulcers}}, strictures or {{c1::Barrett's}} esophagus. An esophageal {{c1::biopsy}} can be used to check for basal cell {{c1::hyperplasia}}, oedema, or {{c1::inflammatory}} findings. Esophageal {{c1::pH}} monitoring can be performed by fixing a small {{c1::pH}} probe in the oesophagus, 5cm above the LES, and recording all episodes in which the oesophageal {{c1::pH}} drops to less than {{c1::4}} over a 24 to 48 hour period.

Currently, the preferred method for establishing GERD as the cause of symptoms (e.g. chest pain, wheezing) is an empirical trial of {{c1::acid}} suppression with a {{c1::PPI}} (e.g. omeprazole, 20mg twice daily), - which normalizes esophageal {{c1::acidity}} in approximately 95% of subjects.

This image reflects esophageal abnormalities present in GERD. {{c1::Inflammation}} injury, mixed acute and chronic inflammatory cells in the epithelium and lamina propria, reactive {{c1::epithelial}} changes, basal and supra-basal cell {{c1::hyperplasia}}, {{c1::elongation}} of the lamina propria papillae, and lack of squamous {{c1::maturation}} of the top. Inflammatory cells in GERD involve {{c1::lymphocytes}}, {{c1::eosinophils (far fewer than in EoE)}}, and {{c1::neutrophils}}.

Complications of GERD involve {{c1::erosive}} esophagitis which is responsible for 40-60% of GERD symptoms. The severity of the symptoms often fail to match severity of the complication. Another GERD complication is esophageal {{c1::stricture}} which results in the healing of {{c1::erosive}} esophagitis. This may need {{c1::dilation}} for treatment. 8-15% of patients with GERD also develop {{c1::Barrett's esophagus}} as another complication. This involves intestinal {{c1::metaplasia}} of the esophagus. It is associated with the development of {{c1::adeno}}carcinoma.

Label the image
1. {{c1::stratified squamous}}
2.{{c1:: transitioning to simple columnar (stomach)}}
3. {{c1::pits of gastric lining of stomach}}
4. {{c1::submucosa}}
5.{{c1::muscularis}}

This is the histological representation of Barret's esophagus. On the left hand side,{{c1::Goblet cell}} accumulation of cytoplasmic intestinal-type mucin can be seen. A universal presence of {{c1::chronic}} inflammation is also observed. Surface glandular epithelium with tall {{c1::columnar}} cells are seen as well.

High grade {{c1::dysplasia}} in Barrett's esophagus can be observed in this image. This involves enlarged {{c1::hyperchromatic}} nuclei with little {{c1::cytoplasm}} left in cells. {{c1::Surface}} involvement is required to distinguish from low grade.
hyperchromatic - nucleus that looks darker than normal

The risk of developing esophageal cancer in Barrett's esophagus is estimated to be {{c1::40-100}} times. {{c1::Endoscopic}} surveillance is recommended for all patients with Barrett's esophagus and is performed every 2 years. {{c1::Biopsies}} are taken from the area of abnormal mucosa, if these reveal {{c1::low}} grade dysplasia, then the frequency of endoscopies is increased. If {{c1::high}} grade dysplastic changes are seen and confirmed by a second pathologist, then the risk of subsequent adenocarcinoma is greater than {{c1::25%}}, and surgical {{c1::resection}} should be considered.

For GERD treatment, the goals are to relieve {{c1::symptoms}} and prevent {{c1::relapse}} and complications. All patients should be advised about {{c1::lifestyle}} modifications that assist with treatment goals. {{c1::Antacids}} or {{c1::antacid-alginate}} combinations are recommended for safe, prompt, inexpensive relief of heartburn.

Lifestyle modifications for GERD treatment involve {{c1::elevating}} the head of the bed 6 inches, stopping {{c1::smoking}} and excessive {{c1::alcohol}} consumption, reducing dietary {{c1::fat}}, reducing {{c1::meal}} size, avoiding bedtime {{c1::snacks}}, losing {{c1::weight (if overweight)}}, avoiding chocolate, carminatives, {{c1::coffee}}, {{c1::tea}}, {{c1::citrus fruit juices}}, tomato juice and cola beverages.

GERD treamtent with medications involves {{c1::H2 blockers}} (e.g. cimetidine (Geramet and Tagamet), famotidine (Pepcid), ranitidine (Zantac, Pylorid and Gertac). Treatment can also involve {{c1::PPIs}} (e.g. esomeprazole (Nexium), omeprazole (Losec), pantoprazole (Protium). 
{{c1::PPIs}} are more effective than {{c1::H2 blockers}}.

H2 blockers - histamine antagonists

PPI shouldn't be used long term
{{c1::Statin}} users show a reduced risk of Barrett's esophagus as well as of oesophageal adenocarcinoma.
**statins may not be as effective for preventing squamous cell carcinoma

The fundus/body of the stomach contain {{c1::surface mucous}} cells. Also contain deep {{c1::glands}} (collectively known as {{c1::Oxyntic}} mucosa) with Parietal cells secreting {{c1::Hydrochloric acid}} and {{c1::intrinsic factor}}, Chief cells secreting {{c1::pepsinogen - pepsin}}, and endocrine cells secreting {{c1::histamine}} and {{c1::somatostatin}}.

Normal fundic mucosa


 The top part of this image shows short {{c1::gastric}} pits lined by pale {{c1::columnar}} mucous cells. The bottom part shows pink {{c1::parietal}} cells that secrete HCl.


The gastric pits are composed of tall {{c1::mucuous}} secreting {{c1::columnar}} cells. With the top box producing {{c1::more}} mucin than the bottom box. The gastric glands are composed of {{c1::parietal}} cells which have brightly {{c1::eosinophilic}} cytoplasm.

{{c1::Chief}} cells are mostly present in the lower half of gastric glands. They are characterized by basophilic/purple appearance due to abundant ribosomal {{c1::RNA}} involved in {{c::pepsinogen}} synthesis.
The antrum of the stomach contains surface {{c1::mucous}} cells and {{c1::mucous}} glands. This includes {{c1::mucous}} producing cells and endocrine cells (G cells) which secrete {{c1::Gastrin}}.

Normal antral type mucosa


{{c1::Mucosal glands}} can be observed in this image.


The lamina propria contains stromal cells, small resident lymphocytes, {{c1::plasma}} cells, {{c1::mast}} cells, eosinophils, blood vessels, and lymphatics. No {{c1::neutrophils}} and no {{c1::lymphoid}} aggregates or follicles are normally present in lamina propria.

Gastritis is the {{c1::inflammation}}, irritation or {{c1::swelling}} of the stomach. It may damage the {{c1::tissue}} of the stomach. Acute gastritis is the short term {{c1::inflammation}} of the stomach with {{c1::neutrophilic}} infiltrate, while chronic gastritis is the long standing {{c1::inflammation}} with {{c1::mononuclear}} cell infiltrate -especially lymphocytes and {{c1::macrophages}}.

Most common forms of gastritis include infection with {{c1::H.Pylori}} and {{c1::autoimmune}} gastritis. Less common forms include {{c1::radiation}} gastritis, chronic {{c1::bile reflux}}, mechanical injury, and {{c1::systemic}} disease (e.g. Crohn's disease, amyloidosis, GVHD).

Acute gastritis is a
-depletion in {{c1::mucosal}} protection system
-{{c1::acid/enzyme}} injury to gastric mucosa
-can be {{c1::erosive}} or {{c1::non-erosive}}
-involves {{c1::inflammation}}, {{c1::erosions}}, and ulceration.

General risk factors/causes for acute gastritis include {{c1::drugs}}, {{c1::alcohol (acute excess)}}, {{c1::bile}}, infections, heavy {{c1::smoking}}, {{c1::chemo}}therapy, acute ill patients/ICU (can involve trauma, sepsis, shock, or extensive {{c1::burns}} such as Curling's ulcer), or {{c1::Neurological}} disease (Cushing's ulcer).

Curling's ulcer - reduced plasma volume leads to ischemia and cell necrosis (sloughing) of the gastric mucosa

Cushing's ulcer - increased intracranial pressure - vagus nerve - hyperactivation of parietal cells (increased HCl)

Acute erosive gastritis has risk factors including {{c1::NSAIDS}}, {{c1::alcohol}}, {{c1::cocaine}}, stress, radiation, {{c1::bile}} reflux. This also exhibits {{c1::haemorrhages}}, erosions, and {{c1::ulcers}}. Complications involve {{c1::bleeding}}, perforation, and {{c1::ulcers}}. Chronic bleeding can lead to {{c1::iron deficiency}} anemia and erosions of ulcers into the arteries can lead to life threatening {{c1::ulcer}} haemorrhage.

In Acute gastritis from H.Pylori,

the infection is usually acquired during {{c1::childhood::time period (age)}}. Prevalence depends on age, {{c1::socioeconomic}} class, and country of {{c1::origin}}. It typically starts as an acute gastritis in the {{c1::antrum}} and is generally {{c1::asymptomatic}}, but as it spreads it can lead to {{c1::chronic}} gastritis. 



Abundant {{c1::neutrophilic}} infiltration is seen in acute gastritis.
Treatment of acute gastritis  involves {{c1::antacids}}, {{c1::PPIs}}, H2 blockers, and the discontinuation of the use of chemicals causing problems such as {{c1::NSAIDS/alcohol}}.

Chronic gastritis has 3 types. Type 1 is {{c1::autoimmune}} gastritis and consists of {{c1::10}}% of cases, Type 2 is {{c1::helicobacter}} gastritis which is {{c1::90}}% of cases, and type 3 is {{c1::chemical}} gastropathy caused by {{c1::NSAIDS}}. The symptoms are {{c1::less::less/more}} severe than acute gastritis but {{c1::more::less/more}} persistent.

Autoimmune gastritis (Type 1) involves progressive {{c1::immune}} destruction. It is also known as chronic {{c1::superficial}} gastritis, chronic {{c1::atrophic}} gastritis, gastric {{c1::atrophy}}, or {{c1::pernicious anemia}}.
This type of gastritis involves ---
-circulating {{c1::auto-antibodies}} (anti-GPC, intrinsic factor, proton pump)
-inflammation and atrophy involving the {{c1::fundus/corpus}} while typically sparing the {{c1::antrum}}
-low secretion of {{c1::acid+/- enzymes}}
-compensatory high serum {{c1::gastrin}} levels
-secretion of intrinsic factor is {{c1::decreased}}
-associated with low serum {{c1::B12}}/megaloblastic anemia and pernicious anemia.
In the image of autoimmune gastritis, moderate foveolar (columnar mucosal cells) {{c1::hyperplasia}} (reactive gastropathy) can be observed with neither {{c1::inflammation}} nor metaplasia.
This image shows absence of {{c1::parietal}} cells, intestinal {{c1::metaplasia}}, and may also see endocrine cell hyperplasia or {{c1::dysplasia}}.
pernicious anemia (attack on parietal cells which lead to B12 deficiency)

Type II chronic gastritis is non {{c1::auto immune}} in origin. The distribution is altered with the {{c1::antrum}} of the stomach being the predominant location. {{c1::Acid}} secretion is often increased. Serum gastrin is generally {{c1::normal}}. This can progress to multifocal {{c1::atrophy}}. Type II is mainly caused by {{c1::H.pylori}}.

The spiral shape and the {{c1::flagella}} facilitate H.pylori passage through the {{c1::mucous}} layer of the stomach. H. Pylori then attaches to gastric epithelial cells by means of {{c1::receptor}}-mediated {{c1::adhesion}}. H.Pylori feeds upon {{c1::mucin}} and are found embedded in the {{c1::mucous}}.

spiral shape, flagella

receptor mediated adhesion

H.Pylori

-The flagella are responsible for bacterial {{c1::mobility}} and {{c1::chemotaxis}}.
-H.Pylori secretes exotoxins involving {{c1::vacuolating}} toxins which cause gastric mucosal injury
-H.Pylori also has secretory enzymes including {{c1::mucinase}}, {{c1::protease}}, and lipase which causes gastric mucosal injury.
- The urease present neutralizes the {{c1::gastric acid}} which causes gastric mucosal injury (by ammonia)
-H.pylori has {{c1::effectors}} (typicaly involved in carcinogenesis) which are responsible for actin remodelling, IL8 induction, host cell grwoth and {{c1::apoptosis}} inhibition.

Consequences of H.pylori infection involve antral predominant gastritis which can lead to {{c1::duodenal ulcers}}, nonatrophic pangastritis which can lead to {{c1::MALT lymphoma}} or asymptomatic H.pylori infection, and corpus predominant atrophic gastritis which can lead to {{c1::gastric}} ulcers, {{c1::intestinal metaplasia}}, {{c1::dysplasia}}, and gastric cancer.
MALT lymphoma can be eliminated by removing all H.Pylori

{{c1::90}}% of patients with Type II gastritis develop duodenal ulcers. {{c1::70}}% of patients have gastritis/gastric ulcer (80-90% if not taking {{c1::NSAIDS}}). In terms of treatment effect, H. pylori clearance leads to ulcer {{c1::healing}}. There is a high {{c1::recurrence}} after ulcer healing without {{c1::bacterial}} clearance.

When diagnosing H.Pylori infection, the following can be used
-{{c1::blood}} test to check for {{c1::antibodies}} to H.pylori
-{{c1::breath}} test for 13C {{c1::urea}} blood test
-{{c1::stool}} test for foreign antigens associated with H.Pylori
-{{c1::endoscopy}} exam to get a biopsy analysed for H.Pylori infection

First line treatment of H.Pylori includes {{c1::PPI}} PLUS {{c1::clarithromycin}} AND metronidazole. These are all given for {{c1::7}} days or in the case of a relapse or maltoma, they are given for {{c1::14}} days.
A regimen of {{c1::PPI}} PLUS {{c1::clarithromycin}} AND amoxicillin can also be given instead.  (Given for the same duration)

This image shows the presence of {{c1::lymphoid}} aggregates in the {{c1::lamina}} propria.
This image is of intestinal metaplasia in gastric antral mucosa. The open arrows show residual {{c1::antral}} type epithelium (normal). The closed arrows show {{c1::intestinal metaplasia}} and the presence of {{c1::goblet}} cells can be observed.

Location: H.pylori in {{c1::Antrum}} and Autoimmune gastritis in {{c1::Body}}
Inflammatory infiltrate: H.Pylori has {{c1::neutrophils}}, subepithelial plasma cells while Autoimmune has {{c1::lymphocytes}} and {{c1::macrophages}}
Acid production: In H.pylori it can be {{c1::increased to slightly decreased}}, while it is {{c1::decreased}} in autoimmune.
Gastrin: In H.pylori it is {{c1::normal to decreased}} and it is {{c1::increased}} in autoimmune.
Serology: In H.pylori, there are antibodies to H.pylori while in auroimmune there are antibodies to {{c1::parietal cells}} (H+ K+ ATPase, intrinsic factor)
Sequelae: H.pylori includes {{c1::peptic ulcers}}, adenocarcinoma and {{c1::MALToma}} while Autoimmune includes atrophy, {{c1::pernicious anemia}}, {{c1::adeno}}carcinoma and carcinoid tumour.

In Type III chronic gastritis which is {{c1::NSAID}} related, there is inhibition of {{c1::prostaglandin}} producion. These protect against acute {{c1::mucosal}} injury due to {{c1::NSAIDs}} and other injurious substances by several mechanism, including stimulation of {{c1::mucus}} and bicarbonate secretion, and maintenance of mucosal {{c1::blood}} flow.
NSAID MOA in gastritis

This is an image of NSAID related gastritis showing moderate {{c1::reactive}} gastropathy involving gastric {{c1::oxyntic}} mucosa.

This image is the previous image zoomed in with the arrow pointing to {{c1::smooth muscle}} fibres in superficial lamina propria (fibres shouldn't be here).

NSAID associated histological features involve {{c1::foveolar (columnar cell)}} hyperplasia, {{c1::oedema}} and increased {{c1::SM fibres}} in the lamina propria, capillary congestion, and a relative paucity of acute and chronic inflammatory cells compared to other gastritis.

NSAID GI toxicity risk factor includes
-prior history of an adverse {{c1::GI}} event (e.g. ulcer, haemorrhage) which increases the risk {{c1::4-5}} fold.
-Age>{{c1::60}} years which increases risk 5-6 fold.
-High (more than twice normal) dosage of {{c1::NSAID}} increases risk {{c1::10}} fold
-concurrent use of {{c1::glucocorticoids}} increases risk 4-5 fold while concurrent risk of anticoagulants increases risk {{c1::10-15}} fold.

Patients with a history of uncomplicated or complicated peptic ulcers SHOULD BE tested for {{c1::H.Pylori}} prior to beginning a NSAID or low dose {{c1::aspirin}}.
If present, this should be treated with appropriate therapy, even if it is believed that the prior {{c1::ulcer}} was due to NSAIDs.

When examining the hands, check for {{c1::clubbing}} (cyanotic congenital heart disease, IE), {{c1::splinter}} haemorrhages (IE, trauma, vasculitis), {{c1::Osler's nodes}} (Rare, IE), {{c1::Janeway lesions}} (non-tender), {{c1::Xanthomata}} (hyperlipidaemia).

A {{c1::sphygmomanometer}} is used to examine BP. Listen for {{c1::korotkoff}} sounds and deflate the cuff at {{c1::2-4}} mmHg/s. The difference between arms should be less than {{c1::10}}mmHg (record higher reading). Look out for {{c1::postural}} hypotension which is a fall in systolic BP of >20mmHg on standing.

When examining the neck, check the {{c1::carotid}} pulse character. Slow rising can indicate {{c1::aortic stenosis}}, collapsing indicates {{c1::aortic regurgitation}}, alternans indicates {{c1::left ventricular}} failure, and jerky pulse indicates {{c1::HOCM}}. A carotid bruit can indicate {{c1::atherosclerotic disease}}.

When examining jugular venous pressure, place the patient at {{c1::45}} degrees under good lighting. The internal jugular vein lies between the 2 heads of the {{c1::sternocleidomastoid}}. JVP reflects {{c1::right atrial}} pressure. The zero point is the {{c1::sternal}} angle and it is normally 3cm above this point. The JVP is visible but not {{c1::palpable}}, it has a complex {{c1::wave}} form, and decreases with {{c1::inspiration}}.

If JVP is >3cm above the zero point, it is abnormal and can indicate {{c1::right ventricular}} failure, {{c1::tricuspid}} regurgitation, pericardial {{c1::effusion}}, {{c1::SVC}} obstruction, {{c1::fluid}} overload.

When inspecting the praecordium, look for scars. A median sternotomy could indicate a {{c1::CABG}} or {{c1::valve replacement}}. A lateral thoracotomy could indicate a {{c1::lobectomy}} or {{c1::pneumonectomy}}. An infraclavicular scar/skin lump could indicate a {{c1::pacemaker}}. Look out for {{c1::pectus excavatum}} (hollow chest), pacemaker box/defibrillator, and check the {{c1::apex}} beat.

When palpating the praecordium, press fingers of right hand lightly against the chest wall to check the apex beat. It is normally located in the {{c1::5th}} intercostal space in the {{c1::midclavicular}} line. A {{c1::heaving}} character can indicate fluid overload/cardiac hypertrophy. A poorly localized apex beat can indicate a {{c1::cardiomyopathy}}. A left parasternal heave can indicate {{c1::right ventricular}} hypertrophy. A {{c1::thrill}} is a palpable murmur.

Systolic thrill - aortic stenosis, mitral regurg
Diastolic thrill - mitral stenosis

When auscultating the praecordium, the bell of the stethoscope is used for {{c1::low}} pitched sounds while the diaphragm is used for {{c1::high}} pitched sounds. Begin with bell at {{c1::mitral}}, then {{c1::tricuspid}}, then pulmonary, then {{c1::aortic areas}}. Follow same pattern with diaphragm.

S1 (First heart sound) indicates closure of {{c1::mitral}} and {{c1::tricuspid}} valve. S2 (second heart sound) indicates closure of {{c1::aortic}} and {{c1::pulmonary}} valve. Feel carotid pulse during auscultation to distinguish better - carotid impulse occurs just {{c1::after}} S1 and S2 occurs {{c1::after}} the impulse. Time murmurs against the pulse, in systole the pulse is {{c1::rising}} while in distole the pulse is {{c1::nonexistent}}.
Aortic closes before pulmonary valve - normal to find "splitting' of S2 (A2,P2)

S1 is heard well with the bell and diaphragm. It is loudest at or near the {{c1::apex}}. A loud S1 could indicate {{c1::tachycardia}} (fever, beta agonists, thyrotoxicosis), mitral {{c1::stenosis}}, left atrial {{c1::myxoma}}. A soft S1 could indicate mitral {{c1::regurgitation}}, MI, left {{c1::BBB}}, {{c1::first}} degree heart block.

Physiological splitting of S2 occurs during {{c1::inspiration::inspiration/expiration}} at the left of the {{c1::sternal}} border, 2nd intercostal space. Abnormal splitting can involve a {{c1::wide}} physiologic splitting of S2 which also occurs during {{c1::inspiration::inspiration/expiration}} and the A2P2 interval widens further (e.g. RBBB, pulmonary hypertension). It also involves {{c1::wide fixed::2 words}} splitting which occurs during inspiration and expiration. The A2P2 interval remains constant (atrial septal defect, RHF). Lastly, it involves {{c1::reversed}} splitting where A2 follows P2 (e.g. LBBB, aortic stenosis).

S3 is a {{c1::low}} pitched sound (best heard with the bell) occuring in mid-{{c1::diastole}}. It has a {{c1::Gallop}} rhythm (KENTUCKY). It originates in the {{c1::ventricle}} from rapid ventricular filling and may be normal in <35 years (>lean people).

Causes of S3 include {{c1::systolic}} dysfunction and high {{c1::atrial}} pressures secondary to congestive cardiac failure. It can also include ventricular or atrial {{c1::septal}} defect as well as aortic or mitral {{c1::regurgitation}}.

S4 occurs in late {{c1::diastole}} and immediately before {{c1::S1}}. It is abnormal at any age. Occurs due to a stiff {{c1::ventricle}} (TENNESSEE). It can be caused by {{c1::hypertension}}, {{c1::ischaemic}} cardiomyopathy, HOCM, or aortic {{c1::stenosis}}.
{{c1::Prosthetic}} heart valve sounds have a clicking/metallic quality - crisp sound.

Characteristics of murmurs include the {{c1::timing}} (systolic, diastolic, continuous), the {{c1::site}} of maximal intensity, the loudness which is graded from a scale of {{c1::1-6}}, the pitch, the {{c1::radiation}} (e.g. to the axilla or carotids), dynamic {{c1::manoeuvres}}, and respiratory variation. Left sided murmurs become louder on {{c1::expiration}} while right sided murmurs become louder on {{c1::inspiration}}.
RIght and LEft (e.g. right increases on inspiration)

Systolic murmurs include {{c1::Pansystolic}} murmurs which can be due to mitral regurgitation, tricuspid regurgitation, and ventricular septal defect, {{c1::ejection systolic}} murmurs which are crescendo-decrescendo, loudest mid-systole or later, aortic stenosis, pulmonary stenosis, HOCM or atrial septal defect, {{c1::late systolic}} murmurs which could be due to mitral valve prolapse.

Diastolic murmurs include early diastolic murmurs which could be due to aortic or pulmonary {{c1::regurgitation}}. They also include mid-diastolic murmurs which could be due to mitral {{c1::stenosis}}.
{{c1::Continuous}} murmurs can be due to a patent ductus arteriosus or an arteriovenous fistula.
Murmurs can also be due to a pericardial friction rub
An easily audible murmur associated with a thrill would be given a grade of {{c1::IV}}. A barely audible murmur would be given a grade of {{c1::I}}.

An easily audible murmur, associated with a thrill, and still heard with the stethoscope only lightly on the chest is given a grade of {{c1::V}}. An audible, but soft murmur is given a grade of {{c1::II}}.

An easily audible murmur associated with a thrill, and still heard with the stethoscope off of the chest is given a grade of {{c1::VI}}. While an easily audible murmur is given a grade of {{c1::III}}.
Dynamic manoeuvres: When listening for aortic regurgitation, lean the patient forward in full {{c1::expiration}} and listen to the {{c1::base}} of the heart.

This brings the base of the heart closer to the chest wall

gets louder with expiration
A murmur of mitral stenosis is exaggerated by asking the patient to roll towards their {{c1::left}} side.
Left lateral position

The {{c1::valsalva}} manouevre is when the patient is asked to pinch their nose with fingers, close their mouth, and breath out hard to pop eardrums. Systolic murmur of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy becomes louder if listened to over the {{c1::left sternal::2 words}} edge. Murmur of mitral valve prolapse becomes louder if listened to over the {{c1::apex}}.

Functional murmurs diminish in intensity when patient {{c1::stands}}, sits or performs {{c1::Valsalva}} manoeuvre. These are localised to the left {{c1::sternal}} border. They are short, early, or midsystolic murmurs of grade {{c1::2}} or less. Innocent systolic murmurs occur in 5-52% of young adults and 29-60% of older persons.

When examining the back, percuss and auscultate the {{c1::lung}} bases to check for {{c1::left}} ventricular failure (pulmonary edema) or {{c1::pleural}} effusion. Also check for {{c1::sacral}} pitting oedema which could indicate {{c1::right}} heart failure.

When examining the abdomen, the patient should be lying with one pillow (if tolerated). Check for tender {{c1::hepatomegaly}}, and for a {{c1::pulsatile}} liver which could indicate tricuspid regurgitation. Check for {{c1::ascites}} (fluid build up) or for an abdominal aortic {{c1::aneurysm}}.

When examining the lower limbs, check for peripheral {{c1::edema}} (pitting/nonpitting). Check the achilles tendon for {{c1::xanthomata}}, check for capillary {{c1::return}} and for trophic {{c1::skin}} changes (shiny with loss of hair). Palpate the arteries, including the {{c1::femoral}}, {{c1::popliteal}}, posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis.

Examination of other miscellaneous areas during a CVS exam, include performing a {{c1::urinalysis}} to check for haematuria (IE), checking the {{c1::fundi}} of the eyes for hypertensive retinopathy or for {{c1::roth}} spots (IE). Also check the temperature chart for IE.

note_models.name: Cloze
